Table of Contents

Enum NotificationPriority

Namespace
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.Enums
Assembly
NeonSuit.RSSReader.Core.dll

Defines the urgency level and presentation behavior of notifications in the RSS reader application.

public enum NotificationPriority

Fields

Critical = 3

Highest urgency: demands immediate user attention and action.

Typical scenarios:

  • Authentication expired — login required to continue syncing
  • Critical storage or database capacity warning (risk of data loss)
  • Security/privacy alert (e.g., potential malicious feed content detected)
  • Complete sync failure preventing any updates for extended period

Behavior:

  • Strong, repeating alert sound/vibration
  • Persistent full-screen or heads-up display requiring interaction
  • Usually bypasses Do Not Disturb / Focus modes (subject to OS rules)
  • Often includes mandatory action buttons (e.g., "Fix Now", "Retry", "Login")
  • Use extremely sparingly to preserve user trust in notifications
High = 2

Elevated urgency: uses persistent or repeating alerts to gain attention.

Typical scenarios:

  • New articles from high-priority/starred feeds or matching critical filters
  • Prolonged feed outage on important sources
  • Significant application events (e.g., major update available)

Behavior:

  • Plays persistent/repeating sound or vibration pattern
  • Shows as a prominent, longer-lasting banner or heads-up notification
  • Higher likelihood of bypassing quiet hours (with user permission)
  • Appears near the top of notification lists
Low = 0

Lowest urgency: completely silent and non-intrusive.

Typical scenarios:

  • Background sync completed without issues
  • Minor status updates or batch summaries
  • Low-priority informational messages

Behavior:

  • No sound, no vibration, no screen wake
  • Appears as a short-lived toast or collapsed notification
  • Stays in notification history but does not demand attention
  • Fully respects quiet hours and focus modes
Normal = 1

Standard urgency: uses a single, non-disruptive alert.

Typical scenarios:

  • New articles from regular feeds (when notifications enabled)
  • Feed successfully recovered from warning/error state
  • Daily/weekly unread digest summaries

Behavior:

  • Plays default notification sound once
  • Shows as a standard toast/banner; persists in notification center
  • May briefly wake the screen (platform-dependent)
  • Most common priority for routine application events

Remarks

This enumeration determines how a notification is delivered to the user, including sound, vibration, persistence, screen wake behavior, and whether user interaction is mandatory. The priority level is assigned when the notification is created, based on the nature and importance of the triggering event.

Priority influences the following aspects:

  • Sound and vibration patterns (silent, single alert, repeating, or escalating)
  • Notification display style (transient toast vs persistent banner/heads-up)
  • Ability to bypass Do Not Disturb / Focus modes (platform-dependent)
  • Positioning in the notification shade/center (higher priorities appear first)
  • Requirement for explicit user acknowledgment or action

Important business rules and guidelines:

  • Use Low and Normal for the vast majority of events to prevent notification fatigue.
  • High and especially Critical should be reserved for genuinely urgent situations that demand immediate user attention.
  • User preferences may override or cap notification priority per category or globally.
  • On Android, each priority typically maps to a distinct notification channel with its own sound/vibration settings.
  • On iOS/macOS, priority affects interruption level and banner style (temporary vs persistent).
  • Default priority for new article notifications: Normal
